Vote will almost certainly be to remove the 2015 Title II Order at the December meeting, but most rules take 30 days to go into effect after publication in the Register and this one says it will not be effective for 60 days after a vote to approve.  Furthermore, the proposed policy would prohibit states from passing their own rules to limit ISPs (as many have said here already)

First, whatever they intend,  they have to actually file a proposed reg, as opposed to issuing a press release.  Then, unless they want to try to get away with declaring an emergency, it has to sit around for a month or two so people can comment on it.  Then the agency has to mull over the comments and either reissue the original reg or file an amended one.  So if words have any meaning, a proposition in which I am daily losing confidence, the agency cannot change its behaviour in any direction until some time after the first of the year.
Perhaps the draft order will offer a timeline.

Standing pat at 25% for now, on procedural grounds. If the FCC doesn't publish a "Final Rule" in the Federal Register before December 1st, this question will effectively close as "No" because time will run out for the rule to become effective before January 1st. That leaves less than two months to go for a "Yes" resolution.

Decreasing slightly for passage of time.  I finally took a look at news around this issue.  It appears quite a bit of noise and support is coming from big tech companies ( Google, Amazon, Facebook ) which I do not quite understand.  There appears to me a clear advantage to large players to do away with regulation.  If Instagram had an extra net surcharge as a start-up, could Facebook have had a better chance of replicating the tech without paying $1 billion?  If I was a shareholder of the large companies I would wonder whether the optimization of public rhetoric for image vs actual actions for shareholder value was being solved correctly.

Nudging upward on news of two FCC commissioner confirmations (https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/08/the-fcc-is-full-again-with-three-republicans-and-two-democrats/), which remove one source of uncertainty about Pai's ability to deliver a decision ending net neutrality rules. @Colin's item re the extension of time to appeal the Supreme Court's ruling upholding Title II regulations is consistent with increasing my probability, but I don't see the FCC's timing as being driven by the SC case.

http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/washington/supreme-court-extends-time-title-ii-appeal/167321
An extension to appeal an SC ruling that upheld Title II regulations has been granted, in case the FCC rules to remove title II regulations. This adds pressure on FCC to move forward with deregulation on a shorter time table or a give a clear signal that they won't be ready to rule before September 28th (deadline to appeal).

The issue is whether they can get a proposed reg out there and commented on as required by the Administrative Procedures Act so that it can take effect before 01 January.  The clock is running on this, and it is possible to imagine that the effective date won't hit before the new year.  Stay tuned.
Current FCC membership lean this way.
news that dt might revisit this

As the link to the FCC's Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) in the More Info makes clear, opening comments on the proposed rules change happened one week ago (July 17th) and reply comments are scheduled for August 16th. That schedule alone would make it challenging - but not impossible - for the FCC to unravel current net neutrality rules prior to 1 January 2018. (I say "not impossible" because I suspect that the FCC Chair has the votes he needs in hand and that a ruling to that effect may even have been drafted prior to the filing of opening comments, leaving only the task of inserting summaries of the opening and reply comments to be done after August 16th.)
This may happen as some have suggested here, but I don't believe it will before the date in this question.

While public opinion is largely opposed to this change, this was also the case for the change to Internet privacy rules that easily passed congress in March 2017. FCC Chairman Ajit Pai seems to not be concerned nor deterred by the push back and large number of public comments against this change. He has stated that it is not the quantity of comments, but the quality, which suggests that they will likely not have an effect on the outcome. He has also indicated that this is a fight that he intends to win. There is a large disconnect between public sentiment and the agenda of people who are making these policy decisions, but ultimately whoever makes the policy will win. While I see this change happening, I'm doubtful that it will go into effect before 1 January 2018. I think that congress and the court system will become involved and that a final ruling may not come down until next year.
No notable progress on this in either direction yet.

seems a fait accompli at this point--if i understand it, the FCC has a 90 day window for public comment, and then it can issue a ruling at any time thereafter. The window ends in September, so what are the chances they will wait? unless Trump and Pence are ousted, or some other unforeseen issue arises, i don't see a reason for them to wait.

This case should be an example of successful lobbying and a pay to play court system in the US.  Title II is the law that is the most efficient at reigning in broadband providers.  It is possible to protect net neutrality using other laws besides Title II, but even the FCC sees the bait and switch coming if they go that route.   If the FCC ceased regulation of telecommunications companies' broadband services, consumers would be forced to join a cartel.  I believe the broadband providers and the FCC know the final verdict will be reduced regulation under Title II, rather than ceased regulation.  Even the uninformed consumer would ask questions when their preferred media slows because it is owned by a different provider than they pay every month.

FCC chairman Ajit Pai has made it clear that he wants to put an axe to internet broadband being under Tittle II. It's already created major pushback, but the commission has 2 republicans and one democrat on it with 2 vacancies[1].  Meaning, to me anyways, that they would be more likely to go down the path of deregulation. While public outrage will likely continue to grow, there have also been reports of bots  being used to make anti-net neutrality comments[2]. Which could provided the FCC with the ammunition it needs to deregulate as Ajit Pai would like

This would be immensely unpopular among grownups.  If the FCC had all been appointed by the current president, that would make it a gimme.  Under the statute, only three of the five members can be of the same political party.  Far as I can tell from the not-very-helpful FCC website, the current prez has a chance to get the third R on before year-end.  The new chair is a notorious opponent of net neutrality.  M. Petits-Doigt can be charitably assumed to have little or no actual knowledge of or interest in the technical, ethical, moral or legal implications of this question, and so will appoint whomever he is told to appoint by his son-in-law or Steve Bannon, whichever one gets to him just before he announces.
